The Moreh, the Moreh was a thorn in their eg eyes.
But M.'s supportedrs headed by the illustrious R. David ben

inquiry.

In this dilemma the pious Salomo took resource to denunciation.
He went to the monks, saying: „Our fellow believers are
heretics and unbelievers induced by the Egyptian Moses (Maimonides),
who has written heretic books, and whereas you remove your
heretics, so clear away also ours and order to be burnt Hebrew
and Hebrew.—But this step also was in vain, as the Christian
religion jurisdiction declared them as liers and informers, and the tongue
of some of them, probably of Salomo himself was cut out,
what caused their death.

In the year 4995 A. M. Abraham, son of Maimonides
in Cahiro was informed of the above stated events and

illustrious father he wrote the Hebrew, by which he
showed the ignorance of the adversaries.

Peace was restored, the Orthodoxy of Maimonides conceded, but
the basis of his philosophical writings still contested and
half a century afterwards the friends of philosophy in the East (Bagdad)
were compelled to pronounce an excummication against all, who
calumniate M. and his books. i.

In the Provence the writings of M. were read with increased ardour,
the family Thibbon especially R. Samuel Abn Thibbon procured
translations and so the Moreh enjoyed numerous patrons and
was approved of by the majority. Spain—of old—the land of sciences,
was at that time oppressed by Christian fanatism, which
raged not with spiritual arms but with fire and sword, and this
had also influence on the Jews. The philosophical studies
were not yet forgot but the florishing times were past.
Therefore R. Salomo Addereth could raise up the minds, ag
and he assisted by the celebrated Talmudist Asher ben Jechiel
interdicted the study of philosophy to all under thirty years
of age. Against this interdiction the friends of philosophy rose,
and as the Champions were tired, peace was desired.

Peace came but it was a sad one. france expelled the Jews,
Spain also afterwards. The oppression during the middle
ages exstinguished all and every spiritual light.

The Champions were banished to different countries, the
whole affair was forgot, the oppression did not admit

an aspiring genius to rise up. But history gives notice
of this excited period in Judaism. The books pro and contra
still exist and should be read in our days, where enlightened
spiritual life is rekindled.

As we have reason to be proud of our ancestor's litterature
at that period, it must be also borne in mind, that
Maimonides and his adversaries lived in an age, where
throughout whole Europe dark midnight governed.

The influence of M.'s writings was and is important at
all times and have ever been an impulse to a liberal
spiritual movement in Judaism.

What in those days could not be accomplished owing to
the iron handed oppression of the middle ages, is reawakened
in our days and expects and claims its solving, viz:
To remove from out fellow=believers superstition as well as unbelief.
